Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Engineered bio-inspired surface for passive flow control
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project stems from the fact that the micro-textured surface proposed in this project can reduce drag - the force experienced by an object moving through air or water. Ground transportation vehicles, airplanes, drones, underwater vessels, wind turbines, and HVAC fans all experience the adverse effects of drag in terms of increased fuel/electricity consumption, increased greenhouse gas emissions, and reduced energy production. Potential efficiency gains using the proposed technology can save numerous industries significant energy costs, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and solve a multitude of problems associated with aerodynamic/hydrodynamic inefficiencies. For example, a 5% increase in efficiency due to drag reduction translates to $5 billion in fuel savings for the trucking industry and the equivalent energy production of an additional 2000 wind turbines per year for the wind energy industry. Micro-textured surfaces for passive flow control presents a unique opportunity in enhancing efficiency in that it can be designed for optimal performance depending on the application to yield the highest possible efficiency gains.

This I-Corps project features a micro-structured coating inspired by shark-skin, which passively modifies the flow close to the surface of an object resulting in drag reduction both in air and water applications. Experimental results performed using the section of a wind turbine airfoil in a water tunnel showed that the proposed micro-structured film, made out of a commercially available polyurethane, can delay and reduce the size of the separation bubble, the phenomenon responsible for increased drag, by 60%. The effect of this reduction on drag was also confirmed in wind tunnel experiments. Reductions of up to 30% and 13% were recorded over an airfoil and a cylinder, respectively. Additionally, enhancements of up to 45% in lift generated by an airfoil was measured when the micro-structured coating was applied to the surface. The ability of the proposed technology to increase fuel and conversion efficiencies will have a transformative impact in many industries including ground transportation, aerospace, and wind energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the completion of the I-Corps program, a better understanding of customer segments, industry and market needs, and the conditions for starting a viable business in aerodynamic efficiency space has been realized. More than one hundred customer interviews in automotive, wind energy, and drone industries have been conducted to determine the customer segment best fit for our current drag reduction technology. The data gathered through customer interviews as well as the training received in the opening and closing cohorts and weekly mentor meetings provided the team with the tools and skills to create a business plan to enter the market. A startup company, Flowraider LLC, has been formed and is currently working on developing a go to market strategy.

Intellectual Merit:

The proposed innovation in this work is a micro-structured coating inspired by shark skin to passively manage flow such that it mitigates inefficiencies, specifically reduces drag and increases lift. This coating, which can be applied as a stick-on film, can be manufactured cost effectively from a variety of materials in large areas.  The flexibility in material selection and the micro-texture parameters allows for tailoring the properties of the film specific to an application considering the durability requirements and performance expectations. The drone propeller segment has been identified as the initial customer segment for entry to market as a result of the I-Corps program. Potential success and validation in this field will allow us to expand our customer segments and explore other viable markets for our technology.   

Broader Impacts:

The proposed innovation is a platform technology that can be implemented in many applications suffering from the adverse effects of aerodynamic/hydrodynamic inefficiencies. The applications include ground transportation vehicles, underwater vessels, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), industrial heating and air conditioning fans, and wind turbines. Potential efficiency gains using our technology can save industries significant costs and help solve a multitude of problems such as detrimental noise and vibrations. Potential efficiency gains from the proposed innovation for instance in ground transportation and wind energy can reduce greenhouse gasses and increases sustainable energy production from wind. While the UAV market has been identified as the initial target market for our technology, the I-Corps program provided us with the tools and fundamental skills for us to develop a go to market strategy for other potential customer segments in the aerodynamic/hydrodynamic efficiency space.
